title: Between 4 October 2019 and 31 December 2019, will anti-government protests in Hong Kong result in three or more fatalities?
preds: Assuming between 4 October and 31 December does not include potential New Year's Eve violence, I think the potential fatalities has all but diminished. It is possible the Chinese approach was to let the protests run their course and it appears to be working. Also, the infiltration of a criminal element into the protests will likely diminish support for the wider movement. I am honestly surprised, though grateful it wasn't worse.

Violence remains, however, HK police have managed to contain it without losing wider control. As the clock winds down on this question, I don't see any significant milestone/event that will spark violence that could lead to fatalities. My forecast is down significantly from earlier in the fall and reflects perhaps overall protest fatigue.
There is likely to be a big protest on 1st January, unlikely to be a further death before then.
Christmas and new year might be a heated time.

As far as I know there seem to have been two so far in that period, one of them only related to the protest (an accident). With only 10 days of a three months time span to go, three or more seems very unlikely to me.

A bit of lost momentum due to legitimate policing:  Police freeze HK$70 million raised by Spark Alliance for Hong Kong protesters, with group suspected of using money for personal gain and rewards: https://www.scmp.com/news/hong-kong/law-and-crime/article/3042840/police-freeze-hk70-million-raised-group-support-hong
lowering possibility of fatalities as it approaches the end of the month.

The violence seems to be abating. The Polytechnique University's issue seems to be clearing up, tho some bombs were disarmed at a high school this week. The question I have is are the HK people becoming tired protest fatigue.
I think it happened but it may be years before the story comes out.
Key drivers of protests, and therefore death-causing events, are subsiding on the time horizon of the question.
Decreasing forecast as tensions have seemed to reside.

Reducing forecast due to changes in local environment. Schools are out or close to release for holidays. There will have to be a significant trigger to boil things over again. This does not include targeted attempts by China and Hong Kong (Chinese Loyalist) to "Enhance" the level of confrontation which may in turn cause fatalities.

Hattip to @Chrisp for convincing me to throw caution to the wind. 
Lets hope the real caution is with the students and the officiers in HK.

The Chinese regime is getting more and more aggressive, 
Like Trump, it can't deal with criticism or (in Hong Kong's case) demonstrations

I hate coming in on this, when random events could so easily prove me wrong. Protests are led by uni students. 
24% Christian.   Actions likely to be peaceful, when they happen. Less likely to happen, due to holidays. School is it will be out,  making coordination more difficult. Riots happen more in summer. This question boils down to next 8 days. Con: lam is likely to move against teachers, and maybe activist students during break. Might provoke.

Between 4 October 2019 and 31 December 2019, will anti-government protests in Hong Kong result in three or more fatalities?
No news is good news. Lets hope it stays that way.

The election seems to have calmed the situation for the moment, it broke the escalating cycle of violence we were seeing. I don't think we will see a return to the violent situations we were seeing in the next few weeks.
I continue to be surprised by resilience of protestors and restraint of Beijing. Lowering but always chance of accident or individual going too far...

Using an optimistic Copernican Principle, there have been no deaths since 14 November (28 days), therefore we can expect there to be none for the next 28 days. Therefore I should drop my prediction once again to close to zero.
However, it's an overly simplified and wildly inaccurate way of forecasting that takes nothing into account other than the the most recent history. 
I'll reduce my prediction once again, this time by half. 
(Still higher than my original prediction)

Between 4 October 2019 and 31 December 2019, will anti-government protests in Hong Kong result in three or more fatalities?
Hundreds of thousands peacefully on the streets to show support.

passage of time
quieting of situation

Between 4 October 2019 and 31 December 2019, will anti-government protests in Hong Kong result in three or more fatalities?
It's been reported that the HK police are more disciplined than previously, so I am backing my forecast down.

This question is going to ruin me!
There is one official death, directly linked to the protest and one debatable death (Alex Chow's fall from the car park) - Video footage proves that his death was not related to the protest. Yes he was in the area, but it was not a protest related death. 
How will GJP record Alex Chow's death? Linked or not? So is the tally at one,  or two?? If I'm predicting for another one death, I'll increase the chances, however if predicting another two deaths, I'd be lowering the score. What to do, what to do....  I'm going for gold - I do not believe Alex's death should be counted as protest related and therefore I'm predicting for another two deaths, which I believe is unlikely.
I'm dropping the score by a third - 7%
I think the chinese will "lose patience" having made "concessions" - they are furious that the protests continue. Its also easy for things to get out of hand.

nEVER UNDERESTIMATE large numbers of bright freedom loving kids. They may be doing a verygood job of defending themselves to begin with and having aid at hand for when things blow out.
<iframe width="560" height="315" src="https://www.youtube.com/embed/gtcmfVR02XI" frameborder="0" allow="accelerometer; autoplay; encrypted-media; gyroscope; picture-in-picture" allowfullscreen></iframe>
I am beginning to think this is getting buried for now.

Between 4 October 2019 and 31 December 2019, will anti-government protests in Hong Kong result in three or more fatalities?
Reducing forecast due to lack of news from the front.
Result of elections may change the outlook of protesters.

Between 4 October 2019 and 31 December 2019, will anti-government protests in Hong Kong result in three or more fatalities?
I am doubling my forecast as protests have resumed in HK despite the election of pro democratic reps.

This weekend's violence has left a few in critical condition, so after the pause, it appears as if protests are ramping up. I revised my estimate down slightly because the pause last week likely gave the security forces a chance to rest and regroup. Despite their levels of violent protest, the HK police have remained remarkably disciplined, but I'm not sure how long it will last.

Between 4 October 2019 and 31 December 2019, will anti-government protests in Hong Kong result in three or more fatalities?
Halving my forecast, it appears the vote was a salve for the demonstrations, at least for a while.
Tensions have subsided. It's close to the end of the year.

Between 4 October 2019 and 31 December 2019, will anti-government protests in Hong Kong result in three or more fatalities? 
Revising downward to reflect the impact of the elections.
Revising dramatically downward. There has been a lull in violence since the election.

Between 4 October 2019 and 31 December 2019, will anti-government protests in Hong Kong result in three or more fatalities?
Increasing my forecast - two Intransigent forces meet in a very small space. I hope I am totally off base to increase but don't see hope yet.
Increasing from 44 on the tone deaf response from Beijing through Lam.
Reducing further based on conversation with @Emil and @Chrisp

The response of the PRC Foreign Minister from the G20 is reasserting government control over HK, despite the elections. I'm trending up, only because once everyone comes down off their election high, they will realize nothing will change, which will bring on more protests and increase the change of a fatality. I couldn't come down below 90% unless Beijing offered some sort of olive branch to HK.

Between 4 October 2019 and 31 December 2019, will anti-government protests in Hong Kong result in three or more fatalities?
I am doubling my probability but my hope is to be wrong and see HK settle down.
Yesterdays elections may be the break this needed to cool off , but something tells me the Chicoms aren't ignoring their rebuke at the polls.

Crowds lead to unpredictable behavior. If there is a stampede in close quarters, three or more could be trampled very quickly like has happened in soccer matches, the Hajj, and elsewhere. It is easy to miscalculate how a crowd reacts or how infrastructure cam magnify miscalculation.
I've been all over the map on this one, can't settle my mind.

The results of the election my quell unrest, but Carrie Lam continues to lack credibility. Her post election statement seems to offer an olive branch, but what will Beijing do with this development? They don’t back down and they don’t reconcile differences very well. After a short peaceful period I expect the violence will return.
Reducing from 81 on the back of the victory of pro democracy candidates in today’s district elections.

Pulling down slightly:
- university protests that dominated headlines have ended without a fatality 
- pro-democracy candidates won big in district elections. This demonstration of will could give pause to more violence which disenfranchises those who aren’t participating My adjustment is tempered by:
- this question is one death away from yes and anything could happen
- systemic issues remain 
- local police and the Chinese gov are taking an increasingly hard line Now go the probability - there have been two related deaths in 8 months of protests. That’s one death every 4 months or a 25% probability. However, all deaths occurred in November so one could argue that more violence is increasing the likelihood of a death. On the other hand, it could be creating a heightened sense of awareness. Dropping to 75%, still 3x my quantitative base rate.

So far, there seem to have been two protest-related fatalities [1]. I am slightly revising downward from 95% on the news that the stand-off at HK's Polytechnic University is coming to an end [2] - however, I think the chance of at least one more fatality between now and the end of the year is still very high. [1] https://www.theguardian.com/world/2019/nov/14/second-death-in-hong-kong-protests-as-xi-demands-end-to-violence
[2] https://www.washingtonpost.com/world/asia-pacific/hong-kong-protesters-trickle-out-from-besieged-campus-as-others-prepare-for-elections/2019/11/22/7f2a9d8a-0c9f-11ea-8054-289aef6e38a3_story.html

Between 4 October 2019 and 31 December 2019, will anti-government protests in Hong Kong result in three or more fatalities? 
Hoping that elections go smoothly with  no fatalities.

I'm disheartened by the increase in violence by the protesters. 
The question is no longer the same as when this challenge started,  it is now "will there be two or more deaths by Dec 31"
I feel that is possible because of the escalation of violence by the protestors. Conversely, the police are showing incredible restraint. If there are no more deaths, this will be testament to the police.

HK police are banning protesters from wearing masks in the run up to the 11/24 elections. No pressure release actions on either side (protesters vs. authorities). It is also worth considering the impact on tensions of external drivers, such as the US and the HK human rights bill that, if signed by President Trump, will enact sanctions and other actions unwelcome to the Chinese government.  I think passage of the bill will accretes to "Yes" for the forecast of this question. No change in my forecast - BTW
Chinese government will try to stop it.
Anticipating additional fatalities unfortunately and believe that some may have occurred after arrest but have yet to be reported.
Violence is escalating and there has already been one death.
Increasing violent police actions, Hong Kong protestors arming themselves with homemade weapons and Chinese military presence to "clean the streets" is the perfect formula for fatalities.

The HK Police are losing their authority through strong-arm tactics that are only antagonizing the citizens. This will increase protests and further erode governmental control over the police. They have been doing a remarkable job keeping casualties low, but as exhaustion sets in they will not be able to maintain their discipline.

It is just a matter of time before the Communist Party decides it has had enough.  Granted, the financial and capital aspects that Hong Kong brings to the Chinese table are significant, but the bottom line is that the Party comes first.  They need time to move the financial mechanisms and then they will step in and end the protests.  We are seeing a ever increasing mainland military presence in Hong Kong now and it's just a matter of time.
Chinese government will try to descalate the conflict, to get back to the baby steps approach in limiting HK independence.
increasing significantly due to major escalation

It's been reported that Hong Kong police storm Polytechnic University as protesters set fires to entrance [1]. It looks like the confrontation is coming to a head. [1]https://www.foxnews.com/world/hong-kong-police-polytechnic-university-protesters-fires

Between 4 October 2019 and 31 December 2019, will anti-government protests in Hong Kong result in three or more fatalities? 
With each day bringing new escalations its difficult to see where this ends.

Increasing from 80% after escalation last night following the morning’s calm. Live rounds were fired. https://www.scmp.com/news/hong-kong/politics/article/3038096/hong-kong-officer-shot-arrow-police-deploy-water-cannons
I wonder if it matters that Hong Kong authorities are starting to describe the killing of the sanitation worker by a brick wielded by a protester as "murder"?

Soldiers called out - only to help with clean up. Seems to be attempt to further vilify protesters with soldiers and citizens cleaning up after former. Combined with increased rhetoric from China, suspect things will be pushed for “resolution”.
https://www.wsj.com/articles/mainland-chinese-soldiers-take-to-hong-kong-streets-for-first-time-since-protests-began-11573907250

Two deaths: Hong Kong Police Say Protesters Murdered a 70-Year-Old Man With a Brick https://www.vice.com/en_us/article/ne8pnw/hong-kong-police-say-protesters-murdered-a-70-year-old-man-with-a-brick) Tensions are very high and the situation remains very brittle in the run up to the elections scheduled for 11/24. More political violence is the expected outcome. When you string together the causal chain of events required to result in "Yes" for the question, all the pieces exist for multiple causal strings of political violence events over the forecast time period.
Per my prior forecast, pushing up due to the second death

Attack on HK government official in London.  Begs the question: would a death in, for example, London, be considered a "result" of anti-government protests in Hong Kong?
https://www.reuters.com/article/us-hongkong-protests-diplomacy/china-strongly-condemns-attack-on-hong-kong-government-official-in-london-idUSKBN1XP0BM
With 2 deaths, probability has to go up!
Increasing due to two quick deaths in the past two days.

Shot protester sounds like they are recovering but elderly man hit by protesters brick has died. Up to two now. Little likelihood of no more deaths by the end of the year as the situation is only getting worse.

From Economist (note second last sentence):
“Many speculate that the government will use the violence to justify imposing a curfew or cancelling district elections set for November 24th, even though Mrs Lam still says she wants the polls to go ahead. Pro-establishment candidates normally perform well at the district level, but this time pro-democracy politicians are expected to make considerable gains. That could unnerve Mrs Lam and the leadership in Beijing, since control of the 18 district councils could give the pro-democracy camp a bigger voice in Hong Kong’s legislature (six out of its 70 seats are reserved for councillors) and in the committee that chooses the chief executive (councillors make up nearly one-tenth of its 1,200 members). On November 12th the People’s Daily, the Communist Party’s main mouthpiece, said that holding “fair elections” would require “decisively” ending the riots. That seems a distant goal.”

It is sad that an 70-year old man died after being hit with brick amid Hong Kong protests. This death is the second fatality in the time frame of this forecast question. (The first one was a student that died from falling off a garage). This latest death may be a game changer because of his age (Chinese culture respects elders) and he was a bystander. In fact, it was reported that he got hit by a brick while he was clearing some bricks voluntarily. This event might trigger some reflection from the protesters and the government.

https://www.theguardian.com/world/2019/nov/14/second-death-in-hong-kong-protests-as-xi-demands-end-to-violence On Monday police shot a 21-year-old student in the stomach at close range and a 57-year old man was set on fire while arguing with demonstrators. A 15-year-old boy is in a critical condition in hospital after he was hit on the head with a teargas canister on Wednesday.
~~~~~~~
COMMENT: 
- 2 deaths have been attributed to the protests thus far
- there's several people in the hospital in critical condition
- there's 7 weeks to go before this question closes
- the election Nov 24th could trigger additional protests EDIT:  @Emil, I haven't found anything more than you did.
Between 4 October 2019 and 31 December 2019, will anti-government protests in Hong Kong result in three or more fatalities? I am increasing my probabilty due to increased sphere of violence.

District Council elections are scheduled for November 24. The outcome of the elections are material to both the pro-establishment and pro-democracy camps. Cancelling or postponing the elections will increase tension on the anti-establishment side, as they will accuse the current government leadership of doing so to maintain a grip on power. Holding the elections poses risks to the establishment of a diminished voice if their candidates lose seats. Thus, the HK security forces have reason to ramp of efforts to maintain order and quell protests in the run up. Increasing my forecast by 5%.

My count so far: * 1 death from falling (from a parking garage)
* 1 person shot at closer range and was in critical condition (haven't been able to find any updates; anybody else?) Additionally:
* "On Wednesday, a 70-year-old man was hospitalized and remains in critical condition after being hit on the head by a brick thrown by a protester, police said." [1]
* "A 15-year-old boy was struck in the head by what is believed to be a tear gas canister and is also in critical condition, according to Hong Kong's Hospital Authority." [1] [1] https://www.cnn.com/2019/11/14/asia/hong-kong-protests-universities-violence-intl-hnk/index.html

Note @GoldenGeezer who is in Hong Kong...
Also to weigh - China very aware of how student movements can end up (May 4 movement, Tiananmen). Believe most had risk of deaths low given “control” on both sides. It seems to have amped up and not entirely sure how it will deescalate. 
https://www.theguardian.com/world/2019/nov/14/hong-kong-protests-foreign-students-start-to-leave-as-unrest-shifts-to-universities

Two serious events - One person fell and died, another shot in the chest.
One probably accidental death.
One self defense because of escalating protester violence. 
I'm increasing my forecast because death has become more probable.
Escalation and more escalation, both from the protesters and the response. I hope I am wrong but I feel the chances are not relatively high of further fatalities.

There have been 4 critical injuries in the protests, including 1 death. These have all occurred over the past 2 weeks for a rate of 2 critical injuries per week. At the current ratio, we’d need 8 more critical injuries in the next 6 weeks. This math would put the odds at about 75%.  Looking at the problem another way, estimates suggest there have been 4,000 injuries since the protests started for a rate of about 250 injuries a week. With 6.5 weeks left in the question that is about 1,600 injuries. At that rate of injuries we’d need to see a 3x increase to raise hit the death toll. Current rates would put the odds close to 11%.  Tho is what is tough on this question, the different base rate methods don’t converge. Splitting the difference would put me at a 43% chance. Another death, though would probably push me into the high 70s. Going to go with the 43% for now.

1 already dead, another protester in critical condition after being shot and now an elderly man is in a sorry state after being hit by a brick. Felt like I should have upped the chance a while back. Nothing looks hopeful there now.

This is now quite likely as the HK Police enhance their response and tactics to restore the rule of law on the streets. Routinely policing appearing to have given way to a more robust type of public order control.

I live in Hong Kong. I can't go to the office this week due to sporadic violence. So far today, we've had: Photos of protestors carrying gas bottles to use a bombs, rumors of students stealing chemicals in their universities to make weapons, videos of other angry citizens fighting back and trying to stone some protestors. It clearly has to get worse before it gets better, so I am upping my percentage. On the other hand, HKers are very controlled, violence in HK is generally more psychological than physical - that's why my initial forecast was so low. However I think we have now crossed the Rubicon and significant amounts of blood will be spilt. 
For today's happenings, see: https://www.scmp.com/news/hong-kong/politics/article/3037453/hong-kong-protests-city-braces-third-straight-day-travel

Protests are intensifying.  There are protests on weekdays now instead of just on weekends.  Protest - police confrontations have spread to the Chinese University of Hong Kong.  The combing force of students from an elite university with high school students and the populous indicates that the protests are not going to die down soon.  At the same time, the government is taking increasing stronger stands to the the protests, with urging from the Chinese government.  There is increasing chance of fatality.

I had dipped down to 60% recently, but have decided to calibrate a bit based on increasing tensional forces. Like tectonic plates, the result with be faulting (more violence and damage), rather than bending or stretching plastically (i.e. compromise or peaceful resolution).

Shoot, I thought I had updated this forecast yesterday!  Darn. There's been one death, and in the last couple of days 2 protestors have sustained serious injuries (shot at close range in the chest and set on fire) which have put them into the hospital in serious condition.   All reports/headlines are about increasing violence.
Slight escalation in violence but also more hardline stance from the Govt.
Clearly things are getting out of hand and police are being pushed to the point of breaking, exactly why is not so clear...

The rhetoric is increasing? From the Economist 
“ Protesters in Hong Kong again blocked roads and rail lines during the morning commute. They also vandalised buses and traffic lights in the city’s central business district during the lunch hour. On Monday evening, Carrie Lam, Hong Kong’s chief executive, described the protesters as “enemies of the people”, promising not to yield to “escalating violence”.”
Updating to take account of the recent (8 November) fatality linked in the news to police action.

Violence escalated yesterday. Two protesters were shot by police. They are in critical condition in the hospital. A man was doused with fire. [1] [1] https://www.nytimes.com/2019/11/11/world/hong-kong-protests.html

Revising from 40% to 60% in light of astounding levels of violence in the past day, which are likely to continue for the next few days as anger builds about the death of a protestor who fell from a parking garage during protests late last week. Moreover - now, in the last 24 hr, a protester has been shot and a pro-government man was set on fire - both are now "fighting for their lives" (they are in critical condition, according to the Hospital Authority) [1]. Total number of deaths so far: 1 (assuming that the young protestor who fell from a parking garage while it was being cleared by riot police counts)
Total number in critical condition: 2 [1] https://www.nytimes.com/2019/11/11/world/hong-kong-protests.html?action=click&module=Top%20Stories&pgtype=Homepage

I thought chances of this were low but more live ammo will increase. Both sides seem to be escalating/provoking. From The Economist this morning...
“Police in Hong Kong fired live rounds at protesters on Monday morning. One man is reportedly in critical condition in hospital after being hit in the upper body at close range. The incident was streamed on Facebook Live. Tensions in the territory have been running particularly high since Friday, when a student succumbed to injuries sustained in a fall from a car park during a protest.”

Protester in critical condition this morning after being shot with live ammunition. I’ve been amazed there haven’t been more than three deaths already, but as there haven’t, despite some hairy moments, I’ve been pretty convinced that there is enough of an element within the protesters, police and Beijing that doesn’t want a body count on this. Now that there is, and the heat is rising the question is can this go six weeks or so without two more?

I'm sad to hear about the Hong man that died falling out of a raised carpark.
It's not conclusive that it was protest related, but it's been counted as such.   The question now changes to: will there be 2 deaths between now and 31 dec?
Two protesters shot today (not fatal), as tensions rise. https://www.washingtonpost/

A protester who fell off a balcony is being called the first death since the protests began. But were there 19 before him?  Look at this . . .   https://www.hongkongfp.com/2019/10/28/hundreds-gather-paper-crane-folding-rally-commemorate-died-hong-kong-protests/

I believe the question defines fatalities as probably excluding the nine deaths that have occurred to date. Deaths, injuries and arrests
Death(s)	At least 9 suicides[18] and 1 indirect fatality from falling[19]
(as of 8 November 2019)
https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/2019_Hong_Kong_protests

Between 4 October 2019 and 31 December 2019, will anti-government protests in Hong Kong result in three or more fatalities? We are nearly half-way thru the period in question with one unfortunate fatality recorded recently.  Hopefully tactics on both sides will moderate as a result. I hope I can reduce my forecast as the future unfolds.

Protests started on March 31st (7 months ago) and the first death occurred on Monday. That would suggest a 14% probability of a death in any 7 month period. Assuming independence (we’ll get back to this in a second) that would be a 7% probability of 2 more deaths in a 7 month period. But there are only 2 months until this question expires, so the answer would have to fall to 2-3%.  However, all large death tolls start with a single death and violence does beget violence to a degree. There is a very real probability that the latest death (on Monday) could stoke tensions that had been placating. I don’t have a great way to quantify this risk, but I believe it exists. As a result, I’m going to bump my 3% up to 11% and see how events unfold.

Unfortunately, first death . Police said they were investigating the case and denied allegations they had obstructed medical assistance or that officers had pushed Chow. A spokesperson for the Hong Kong government expressed “great sorrow and regret”. Quote from a Financial Times article on 11/8
I think it's quite unlikely, however 3 is a relatively small number, and just one unfortunate event could cross that threshold. Tension is still high, so that's how I've come to 20%.
Updating on news of accidental fall from parking garage, which I assume counts.

Agree with @cdob63 that the recent death of a student [1,2] probably qualifies as a protest-related fatality. This is inflaming tensions, especially given that the police may have played some role in it - "An emergency responder, who spoke on condition of anonymity because of the sensitivity of the incident, said officers tried to make rescuers leave as they were treating the injured student. They also blocked an ambulance from approaching, the emergency responder said" [2]. In other news, yet another lawmaker was stabbed two days ago [3]. Increasing probability by 15% as a result. [1] https://www.wsj.com/articles/hong-kong-student-dies-after-fall-during-protester-police-clashes-11573200194?shareToken=stf82e0f19d55543f598a92d765eb6aad8
[2] https://www.nytimes.com/2019/11/07/world/asia/hong-kong-protest-student-dies.html
[3] https://www.bbc.com/news/amp/world-asia-50312310

https://www.reuters.com/article/us-hongkong-protests/death-of-hong-kong-student-likely-to-add-fuel-to-unrest-idUSKBN1XI07H
Presumably this meets the criterion of a fatality that resulted from a protest, although it was clearly an accident.  Coming up some on the assumption that street action will become more agitated and so will the authorities.  That's how people get hurt in these situations.

The wood pile is still soaked with gasoline. All that is needed is a match. Tension remain high. The challenge in forecasting such an event is that it is low frequency, high impact.  https://www.reuters.com/article/us-hongkong-protests/china-backs-bolder-action-to-counter-roots-of-hong-kong-unrest-official-idUSKBN1XG09W

Updating for the passage of time. I don't like this question; Wikipedia tells me there have been ten deaths so far (possibly all before 4 October), but all suicides. Would these count as fatalities in interpreting this question?

The base rate is relatively low. It is also worth noting that organizers' strategy is likely to shift toward turning out people to vote, which, seems to me, decreases the chances of violence. References:
[1] https://multimedia.scmp.com/infographics/news/hong-kong/article/3016815/hong-kong-protest-city/index.html
Shifting down a few points for passage of time but the situation remains tense and ripe for small miscalculations to spiral quickly.
Decreasing forecast for passage of time and seeming decline in protests (or at least protest reporting).
However, the quest for a dangerous balance..
"Hong Kong protests: Knife attacker bites man's ear after stabbing four" https://www.bbc.com/news/world-asia-china-50281914

Unsure why the crowd has begun forecasting this down so much - passage of time can't account for such a steep drop. I'm forecasting up by 5% because of indications that China will push through a security overhaul and implement "patriotic education" in HK. https://www.wsj.com/articles/china-pushes-to-integrate-hong-kong-through-patriotic-education-security-overhauls-11572617038

https://www.reuters.com/article/us-hongkong-protests/downtown-hong-kong-becomes-battleground-as-night-falls-idUSKBN1XC03J?il=0
Coming up a bit.  It is possible to wonder whether there are in the protest movement some elements interested in bringing about some fatalities in the hope that this will inspire more, and more agitated, protests.  Stay tuned.
Adjusting down slightly tensions have remained steady, but violence is low
so far there are no fatalities and the parties seems to look into resolution
Neither side wants to give in.  I feel the protests can only escalate.  I fear there will therefore be some fatalities
Adjusting down as crowd sizes shrink and the govt looks for a resolution - one that could be jeopardized by casualties. Situation still remains volatile..

Two months to go. Who knows how this will unfold; riots like this can lead to revolution, which would surely produce fatalities and possibly (although not likely in this case) replace the system of government. I can see a clash between protestors and police / military leading to accidental fatalities, but I expect the authorities will try very hard not to let that happen. My warmest thoughts and best hopes for those involved.

Raahul always eat his Panda Cheese. I see no possible problem of violence. Won't you join me in a nice tasty slice of panda cheese? Because if you don't .... https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=XYz3sl0LEA4
https://www.scmp.com/news/hong-kong/law-and-crime/article/3027006/communication-problem-led-hong-kong-police-officer

The base rate implies that the probability of fatalities occurring is extremely low. There appears to have been 0 deaths resulting from anti-government protests since the 1997 handover of HK from Britain to China, as @KitsonJ has pointed out. However, as many others have noted, there is good reason to give little weight to this base rate given how enormous this protest movement is and how great of a threat it is perceived to be by Beijing, especially relative to past protest movements in HK. So instead, I will mostly consider the base rate to be the fatalities/near-fatalities thus far in this current protest movement. The ongoing protest movement has gone on for 196 days, and the protests have been violent since July 1 (when protestors stormed the Legislative Council Complex), for a total of 104 days so far [1]. There are 79 days from now until Dec. 31. In the previous 196 days, there have been 0 fatalities as a result of the protests and, for my purposes, 2 near-fatalities. One of these near-fatalities was the use of a live round against a protestor on the 70th anniversary of the founding of Communist China [2], resulting in a chest injury. The other was the use of a "sharp object" by a protestor against a police officer, resulting in a "bleeding neck wound" [3]. Neither of these incidents seem to have been life-threatening, but I count them as near-fatalities because a slight variation in where the bullet hit in the first case and how deep the stabbing wound was in the second case could have made these situations life-threatening. Please let me know if there have been other altercations that could have been similarly life-threatening in slightly different circumstances. So, there have been 0 fatalities and 2 near-fatalities in the 196 days of the protest movement and 104 days since the protests became violent with the storming of the Legislative Council Complex. This includes the time around and on the day of the especially sensitive 70th anniversary of the founding of Communist China on and around Oct. 1 - to my knowledge, there are no similarly sensitive anniversary dates looming between now and the end of the year. Given this base rate, I find it very unlikely that there will be at least three protest-related fatalities if things continue as they have been - perhaps just ~5% (the moment a first fatality ever occurs, I will revise this upward to 20%). I think the most likely scenario that would result in at least three fatalities is a 1989 Tiananmen Square-style crackdown. According to most experts, the next 79 days of the year will most likely feature Beijing playing a waiting game in which they hope that the protest movement will die off on its own. Experts do not expect Beijing to either give in to the protester's demands nor to embark on a 1989 Tiananmen Square-style crackdown (such a crackdown would almost certainly result in at least three fatalities). I think Evan Osnos, who reports on China for The New Yorker, puts Beijing's strategic thinking best: "I would not expect that they're going to give into the protestor's demands, frankly there is no indication in Bejing...(that) China is ready to make a deal with HK...but at the same time, there are very real pressures on Xi Jinping to not handle this the way it was handled in 1989...if they went into HK with tanks...this would devastate a financial capital that is very important to China's economy...and more importantly, it would devastate China's effort to establish itself on the global stage as an alternative to American leadership. The more likely scenario is that China would keep up the pressure and would gradually use its sheer weight and persistence to grind down the resistance of protestors in HK" [4]. Moreover, according to other experts, "armed intervention in Hong Kong would also provide political leverage for Xi's factional opponents" and "Xi will also be thinking of cross-strait relations with Taiwan, which have only worsened since the Hong Kong protests began in June." [5] But on the other hand, this has gone on for long enough that some experts think that Bejing's patience may be running out and that the situation will at some point involve intervention by the People's Armed Police [6,7]. Veterans of the Tiananmen see such a crackdown as inevitable [8]. If the waiting game does not work out, Beijing may be forced to intervene. I assign such a crackdown by the mainland before the end of a year a probability of ~25%. I assume this will, in all cases, result in at least 3 fatalities.  TL;DR: 5% chance of 3+ fatalities if protests continue as they have been + 25% chance of a 1989-style crackdown that will result in 3+ fatalities in nearly all cases = 30% of 3+ fatalities. [1] https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/2019_Hong_Kong_protests
[2] https://www.nytimes.com/2019/09/30/world/asia/china-national-day-hong-kong-protests.html
[3] https://www.apnews.com/613462a6acbb429c9d36cf47ac65d485
[4] https://www.newyorker.com/podcast/the-new-yorker-radio-hour/will-hong-kong-bring-china-to-the-breaking-point
[5] https://www.cnn.com/2019/10/12/asia/xi-jinping-balancing-act-hong-kong-intl-hnk/index.html
[6] https://www.economist.com/china/2019/10/01/hong-kong-tries-its-best-to-spoil-chinas-big-anniversary
[7] https://www.economist.com/open-future/2019/10/11/hong-kongs-internal-contradiction-of-one-country-two-systems
[8] https://www.economist.com/china/2019/10/10/tiananmen-veterans-view-hong-kongs-crisis-with-fatalism

I'm actually using this questions with my AP Stats students to have them practice forecasting. There's only five students plus me, but this was our aggregate forecast after using the history of protests as a starting point to come up with subjective probability estimates of witnessing a fatality, and then taking into account the 80 day time frame left and the fact that we need to witness at least 3 deaths.  From there, because we got a low initial estimate (1% chance), we looked for counter-examples on here that gave pertinent facts about tensions escalating and damage already being done in the form of firebombs and vandalism, and we learned about the history of Chinese/Kong Kong protests in particular. We found a lot of this convincing, which brought us to the 52% estimate seen directly below. But we got ahead of ourselves and forgot to take into account the wisdom of the crowd, which moved our needle up further to 60%. I have no doubt some of our initial probability estimates were off, but I believe my students did a good job of letting new information update their priors and were great at listening to counterarguments. We'll see how we did by the end of the year.

To forecast this question, one needs to understand the history of Hong Kong and its protest movements. Background: Hong Kong was ceded to Britain in 1842 and has been a British colony until 1997 when it was handed back to China.  As residents in a colony, Hong Kongers did not have much say in the colonial government.  In anticipation of the handover, UK gradually transferred its administration to local control.  The “Basic Law” negotiated between UK and China became the mini-constitution for the governance of HK.  China declared the use of “one country, two systems” in the management of HK for the next 50 years. The optimistic assumption (by UK and Hong Kongers) is that over time China will liberalize its political system as it grows economically, which makes it easy to integrate HK into China by 2047.     In the twenty plus years since the handover, China becomes an economic power.  But while loosening its grip on its citizens on some matters, it maintains strict controls of all things political.  It maintains the infamous internet “Great China Wall” which blocks anything that the Chinese government considered objectionable.  Hong Kongers just have to step over the border to Shenzhen to experience the differences.   Recent events indicate that China is becoming more totalitarian instead of liberalizing.  Several Hong Kongers have disappeared (i.e. kidnapped) into China to face politically related chargers.  This creates fear in HK, especially the young people.  Think of it this way, if you are a twenty-something, you and your family are likely to lose a lot of your freedom when you are in your forties.  There is not much hope for them if the system does not change now. This is the reason why the young people are taking the matter in their own hands and protesting now, with the hope of changing the trajectory of history. Past protests in HK: There were unrests in HK in the pre-handover days.  Most of the unrests died down with no casualties.  However, the unrest in 1967, which lasted several months, resulted in more than 50 deaths [1].  This unrest started with a labor dispute. It grew bigger as it got inspiration from the Cultural Revolution in China at that time.  Bombs and clashes between the police and protesters resulted in the 50-plus casualties.  The 1967 unrest is a reminder that loss of life in unrests in HK could and did happen. There were many large-scale protests after the handover.  Most of them were peaceful and related to events in China (e.g. commemoration of Tiananmen Square Massacre) and calling for universal suffrage.  Practical all of the demonstrations did not result in much improvement in democracy.  The 2017 “Umbrella Movement” lasted 2 months with the occupation of the Central District, but again it failed in achieving its goals.  After the fizzling out of the Umbrella Movement, the government started arresting activists.  This is a reminder to the current protesters that failure is not an option. Current Protests: The current unrest started with the opposition to the proposed extradition law and evolved into many other things: police brutality, universal suffrage, etc.  Both sides are increasingly more violence, from the use of tear gas to live ammunition by the police, and from traffic blockage to firebombing by protesters.  The recent introduction of emergency ordinance appeared to increase the anger of the protesters. The tactics used by the police (and its sympathizers) and the protesters could easily result in fatalities.  Two protesters have been shot since the start of the protests 4 months ago.  These two incidents could easily result in fatalities.  So is firebombing and mob beating of individuals.  Right now, I put a 75% chance of having at least 3 fatalities in this protest movement.  I will be watching the situation closely to see what happens after the declaration of emergency ordinance and adjust my forecast accordingly.  [1]  https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Hong_Kong_protests

HK is being very careful to impose laws that allow for incarceration without resorting to violence [1] and the threat of China coming in to enforce peace is very likely, given that the protestors are fighting harder now that the HK administration is coming down harder on them [2].  The current law keeps China out, but they can send troops as needed [3], though I wonder who would enforce that law right now if China violated it.  Britain has plenty of their own problems to manage, the US seems to be running away from democratic complainants either to avoid issues or as a favor to those in the position of power, and there doesn't seem to be much of a unified coalition to oppose China moving in to preserve security and economic/social stability except through sanctions and diplomatic measures.  Although China isn't in the strongest position now and they have been conservative about taking aggressive positions that they haven't prepared for well in advance and are generally well-prepared to handle, I think they would be more willing to move in before the protests lead to general chaos than to let them become a trigger or signal for something less manageable now or in the future.  And China will want something that can be done behind the scenes or done without state violence, and do it quickly and efficiently.  There have already been rumors and official clarifications of fatalities [4], and unless someone dies on the street in front of a camera, I wonder how clear the fatality outcome will be. Forecasting on Chinese/HK mentality can be complicated, especially for me as I have no relation at all with this. On one side, there is an escalation of violence, apparently from both sides: "Police had warned that officers feared having to shoot people in order to protect themselves. In this case videos showed protesters viciously attacking a policeman on the ground before a colleague ran towards the group and fired at Mr Tsang... The officer who used the gun also carried non-lethal weapons." [1]. And "Five police were hospitalised, including one with third-degree burns, allegedly caused by corrosive fluid thrown by rioters." [1]. If it is the intention of the HK government to calm things down, certainly violence and fatalities will not help. However, this might not be their approach to unrest anymore, as seems apparent from the invocation of the Emergency Regulations Ordinance on October 4th [2] banning the wearing of masks as only measure. This happened right after Carrie Lam (HK Chief Executive) returned from the 70th anniversary of Communist Party massive military demonstration "Mrs Lam denied that anyone from the central government had asked her to issue the edict during her visit. But after her announcement, a central-government spokesman said that banning masks was essential. " [2]. Apparently, today a "Hong Kong court rejects mask ban challenge" [4]. Not mentioned anywhere, but maybe even Ms Lam's position was at risk for a tougher ruler. So, it seems that violence is escalating and the HK government is taking a tougher position, making the fatalities more likely. However, I'm unclear about the consequences of this outcome, from internationalisation to rejections from more peaceful groups of protesters ("Hong Kongers know how to protest", a short but good summary here [5]) or, when properly manipulated, justification for a Chinese intervention, unimpressed by the Sino-American commercial war and a troubled (?) Trump, and concerned about "democratic contamination" to mainland.

TLDR; The base rate is low, but this is a situation which has some sticky factors in that neither side wants to back down and has no incentive to do so with 3 months to run. There have been 16 HK police officers killed since 1983, (none in a demonstration) which is roughly 1 police death every 2 years, the last one was in 2018. (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Gallant_Garden) As far as I can tell, a protestor in Hong Kong has not been killed at least since the handover of power in 1997. No protestors were killed in the 2014 Umbrella protests, although there was around 500 injuries in civil conflict which lasted 2 and a half months. The Hong Kong protests began 31st March of this year, and there has not currently been any fatalities on either side. 2 protestors have been shot in the last week, one in the chest, one in the leg, by a HK standard police revolver which is 90% likely to be a derivative of a smith and wesson model 10. These are not especially powerful handguns, and it seems that protestors who are injured are being looked after despite their injuries. It is still possible that these two protestors who have been shot may die (would that count towards the three total need for the resolution?) but reports have suggested they will not die.  Considering what will happen if the civil conflict escalates is important to the resolution of the question. The next step is probably a declaration of emergency, invoking the "Emergency Regulations Ordinance" which “make any regulations whatsoever which he [or she] may consider desirable in the public interest” if she (Carrie Lam) considered it an occasion of “emergency or public danger” if she believed the police were likely to lose control of the streets. This could be sparked by fatalities or simply loss of the ability to control the demonstrators. Lam may "call in the Chinese" but this will NOT be the Peoples Liberation Army but the Peoples Armed Police, who are trained in riot control. (https://www.reuters.com/investigates/special-report/china-army-hongkong/) The HK police and the PAP know that protestor deaths will work against them and their ability to maintain "stability" in the territory. I do not think the HK authorities or the CCP will back down, nor do I think the demonstrators are ready to do so. The situation is different to the 2014 protests, China has become more centralised under Xi Jinping, and with few consequences for dealing with HK from the west he has significant freedom of movement.   This does NOT mean fatalities, as demonstrators do not have access to weapons aside from improvised ones, and the police are going to want to avoid fatalities, as is the PAP if they are deployed.   The HK police are currently stretched by the demonstrators, they will undoubtably be tired, frustrated and low on morale that they have thus far failed to contain the demonstrations as they have increased in ferocity (from @Anneinak - "On National Day, police fired about 1,400 rounds of tear gas, 900 rubber bullets, 190 beanbag rounds and 230 sponge-tipped rounds. By contrast, they had fired 3,100 tear gas rounds, 590 rubber bullets, 80 beanbag rounds and 290 sponge-tipped rounds between June 9 and Sept. 20.")  I think if fatalities occur they are likely to be caused by the HK police, in a situation where they believe they have no other alternative than to discharge their firearms. The shots which have been fired are lucky in that they have not yet caused fatalities, especially the protestor shot in the chest, a couple of inches the other way and he would have been dead. Three fatalities can be reached very quickly in street violence. There does not seem an easy way to climb down for either side, and the intensity of the protests could well mean that we are about to see the first few casualties in Hong Kong, despite the very low base rate.
Xi Ping words toning things down, numbers of protestors dropping

https://www.nbcnews.com/think/opinion/after-hong-kong-protester-shot-cycle-violence-threatens-more-tragedy-ncna1062431 Oct. 4, 2019, 
By Ying Ma
A tragedy appears ever more imminent in Hong Kong. As anti-government, anti-Beijing protests continue into their 17th week, clashes between law enforcement and protesters have become increasingly ugly and more violent. On Tuesday,. . .an 18-year-old protester in Hong Kong was shot in the chest with a live round by the police. It has become commonplace for the radical elements of the city’s democracy movement — namely, young protesters — to do battle with the more powerful police force. Weekend after weekend, violence rages on. Unless something changes, it is only a matter of time before a real tragedy involving fatalities occurs. Further escalation in violence could also lead to a much more severe crackdown by the Hong Kong government or a military intervention by Beijing . . .  The young protesters have resorted to violence because they believe it to be effective and necessary in their fight against Beijing’s encroachment upon their city’s autonomy under the “one country, two systems” system, the Hong Kong government’s ineptitude in safeguarding their rights or offering hope for their future, and the rampant police brutality that has come bearing down on their movement. Numerous marches, rallies, protests and sing-alongs — numbering hundreds of thousands, and at times millions — have been peaceful, touching and inspirational. They have also reflected the frustrations common among broad segments of Hong Kong’s population. Yet, peaceful protests on their own did not win concessions from Beijing. In July, when violence broke out and protesters stormed the Legislative Council, Hong Kong’s parliament, the movement saw concrete results. The city’s chief executive declared dead the controversial proposed extradition bill that had set off the protests. As violence escalated, she ultimately withdrew the bill. The protesters noticed and so did democracy activists who have historically advocated for nonviolent civil disobedience. The excessive use of force by the police has been a rallying cry for protesters as well, and has galvanized support for the movement across Hong Kong society. . . .  The youngsters on the front lines . . .  have responded by actively engaging in arson, vandalism, road blockades, brick and petrol-bomb throwing and destruction of public property. Their resistance is not sporadic, but systematic and organized. The protesters’ trashing of Hong Kong’s metro stations has now become routine. About half of the city’s 91 stations have been damaged. . . .
. . . 
Violence begets more violence. After four months of protests, both sides — police and protesters — have dug in. The police force, until recently known as “Asia’s finest,” have plenty of their own grievances, and see the protesters as thugs, hooligans, rioters and terrorists. Violent clashes have left them bloodied and on edge. In July, one officer had part of his finger bitten off by a protester. On China’s National Day, the most violent day of protests, multiple officers were injured with a corrosive liquid, with one incurring third-degree burns. Meanwhile, the police vigorously defend the shooting of the 18-year-old protester, noting the officer’s life was threatened as he attempted to rescue a colleague who had been thrown to the ground and was being attacked with bricks and sharp objects by about 10 protesters. On National Day, police fired about 1,400 rounds of tear gas, 900 rubber bullets, 190 beanbag rounds and 230 sponge-tipped rounds. By contrast, they had fired 3,100 tear gas rounds, 590 rubber bullets, 80 beanbag rounds and 290 sponge-tipped rounds between June 9 and Sept. 20. U.S. lawmakers have worried that Beijing will deploy the People’s Liberation Army amassed across the border in the city of Shenzhen to quell Hong Kong’s unrest. (Hong Kong Chief Executive Carrie Lam has said that Beijing “has absolutely no plan to send in the PLA.”) Indeed, Beijing insists it wants to avoid a bloody crackdown like the one at Tiananmen Square in 1989, where peaceful pro-democracy student protestors were massacred. Nevertheless, an escalation in violence does not require the PLA. Police officers, believing their lives are in danger, could ramp up their tactics. On Tuesday, although only one protesteor was shot with a live round, five other live rounds were fired throughout the city, some as warning shots. ~~~~~~~
COMMENTS
Fatalities is a high bar. However, I assume China has embedded agents provocateurs in the crowds who might cause events to escalate. This article paints an ominous picture.  While some news outlets have referred to the protests as peaceful, this writer says, "Weekend after weekend, violence rages on." But, note the ending sentence I quoted:  ". . . five other live rounds were fired throughout the city, some as warning shots."  Uh-oh.
The rumor mill has it that protestors are being snatched by PRC agents and disappearing to the Organ Farms. That'll motivate some youngsters to do desperate things to escape.

It seems like a strong strategy for the Chinese government to be patient and avoid media attention to these protests as best they can. Fatalities obviously undermine that. Given growing news about Trumps impeachment and Brexit, they may just want to keep this off the front pages for the time being. There have been no fatalities so far, so it seems that those disciplining the protest are disciplined in that way. Of course, I am going on the assumption that suicides do not count as fatalities, as there have been 8 suicides so far. If suicides count, I would absolutely raise my prediction a large amount.
I live in Hong Kong and violence has been contained.

Starting to look not just nasty but probably fatal.   One dimly suspects that some among the protesters would welcome a few fatalities (as long as they are other people) in the probably mistaken belief that this would get The Big Kids to take some sort of action against Beijing.  But there are many ways in which this is not 1989, mostly having to do with money.  I would love to be wrong about this.
I anticipate further escalation.  Probability of a Berlin Wall-/Velvet Revolution-style peaceful resolution is very low
Nobody in either HK or the PRC wants this, but things happen.  2 is probably too high, though.

Despite getting more and more violent, fatalities are exceptional at Hong Kong. Hong Kong residents are docile and love to live in thier city under the dark clouds of regime. So, three or more are far fetched possible.
